description: This course analyzes financial problems corporations face that result from operating in an international environment. Major topics covered are corporate strategy and the decision to invest abroad, forecasting exchange rates, international portfolio diversification, managing exchange risk, taxation issues, cost of capital and financial structure in the multinational firm, and sources of financing.
name: INTERNATL CORP FINANCE

values.comments:
*Finance 731 covers issues related to both international financial markets and the financial operations of a firm within the international environment.  The first part of the course examines issues related to the international markets.  The second part of the course considers financial issues associated with the operation of a firm in the international environment. While the course discusses theoretical basis on the various issues, it relies on both empirical evidence and discussion of firms' real world activities.  The course style is mostly lectures with some class discussions.  It evaluates students through several quantitative problem sets, case studies, and a midterm and end of course exam. 

Overall, students thought this was a “superb course” and one that was “full of learning.” Students learned a wealth of information on “how to handle international finance” and found that this complemented Corporate Finance and Advanced Corporate Finance, without overlapping. 

Students raved about Professor Bodbar’s ability to make a “very dry subject very interesting.” They found him “engaging,” “knowledgeable,” and “passionate about the subject.” Students enjoyed the way Professor Bodnar brought real world knowledge and situations to the classroom. One student praised the way Professor Bodnar “treated the students as learners and professionals” and said that he “challenged us to learn, but in a way that encouraged learning.” Several students called Professor Bodnar one of the best professors they have had at Wharton.

Though students raved about the overall course, many complained about the large amount of work assigned, warning that students who do not keep up are “fried during the exam.” Students also reported that those who are slower with mathematical computations are at a “distinct disadvantage in the exams, as the time constraint is significant.” They suggested that these issues would be resolved if a problem set was cut or if there was “more formal TA-led drilling or support.”

*This review is based on only 7 student comments
